segments.text: I'm Martin P. Sutter, and I'm a native of the Midwest.
I grew up in a very small town in Michigan, came down to LSU on a basketball scholarship way, way, way back when, when short white guys still could get basketball scholarships.
That was back in 1972, 73.

And how I really tied into Mitchell was I initially started studying chemical engineering at LSU and later switched over to business and finance, but went to work with a CPA firm initially out of school.
Pete Marwick here in Houston.
But after about two and a half years of being more in financial advisory services and that,
there was enough of that engineer in me that wanted to grab onto something nuts and bolts.
And that's when I took a very, really radical diversion from what you would consider purely financial business into the operational side of Mitchell.
I went to work in the transmission and processing division of Mitchell Energy back in 1979.
And those were exciting times for Mitchell, the late 70s and early 80s, when, number one, hydrocarbon prices accelerated quite a bit.
But more importantly for them, Mitchell has, I guess, always been regarded as a small oil producer, a medium-sized gas producer, but a giant in natural gas liquids.
And that's the area that I was in.
And about that time, they
Historically, there were controls on the price of natural gas liquids, and those came off.

Mitchell, as a low-cost producer, benefited largely from that, such that at the peak in my several years in the transmission and processing division, we are generating about $100 million a year of operating profit.
That was clearly the highest growth area of Mitchell.
And I worked for Bruce Withers, who was the president of that division, and was involved in a variety of things that I think made me very visible to Mitchell Senior Management and offered...
In what sense?
Well, if we would be involved in an acquisition, I would somehow...
get put on that acquisition team as someone who had some technical understanding but also had financial skills.
I was involved in the
The acquisition, we made a couple major plant acquisitions back in those days.
We also turned down some major acquisitions, which were probably, in retrospect, my biggest contributions to the energy side of the business.
We had looked at being a participant in the MAPCO pipeline, which I recommended against, and we had been...
looking at being the participant and the acquisition of a major fractionation facility down in Mount Bellevue, and I recommended against that as well.
So I had just gotten good exposure to a variety of people senior to Mitchell's management, but particularly I had a very good relationship with Bruce Withers, who is the president of that division.
I really consider Bruce as my mentor.
He was one of the smartest, certainly one of the toughest negotiators I had ever experienced.
My understanding was that, in terms of venture capital, that Mitchell

had really begin to wonder, ask questions relating to venture capital going back into the 70s, even though I think, as I recall, they might have formed a venture capital subsidiary somewhere between 81 and 83, legally formed a subsidiary, but the venture capital subsidiary didn't become operational until 1983-84 when I came in to run it.

One of the stories we heard, and I think it was from Mr. Richmond, is that, and we were wondering if this is apocryphal or whether it really occurred, maybe you would know, he said that about that same time, 81, 82, that Mr. Mitchell determined that in order to, in fact, fund or encourage
the development of the woodlands of clean, high-tech kinds of corporations.
He realized he was going to have to nurture that in one way or another.
So he created the Venture Capital Company in about 30 seconds, he said, or something like that.
Asked in the hall or something.
In the hall of Venture Capital.
you know, one of the office buildings, and gave it, I think there wasn't a Richmond, and said, make it happen, kind of thing.
Right, right.
Have you heard that story?
Yes, and, you know, again, that precedes me in venture capital, and I've heard versions of that, but that's pretty close to the general theme of it.
And like Mr. Mitchell, he...
Even going back before that, though, Mr. Mitchells had asked the question for years, why aren't we seeing in Texas more compact computer stories, more high-technology companies evolve?
And there were a lot of reasons for that, but one that kept coming back and back was that Texas was not rich in venture capital.
We are historically rich here in risk capital, but not in professional institutional venture capital.
And one of the things about George Mitchell is that when he believes something is necessary, he'll try to
perhaps rally those that are in a better position or more appropriate to do it to do it.
But if they won't do it, he'll say, well, it looks like we'll have to do it type of thing.
And so I think a lot of that went into it.
But initially, the concept within the Mitchell management was that the venture capital subsidiary would be something to support
the growth and development of the woodlands, which wasn't necessarily a good strategy, and I'll lead into that.
About that same time, again, looking in 1983, I think Mr. Withers recognized that I was looking for a new challenge, and I had really, bless his heart, he had...
advanced me.

I don't remember six or eight months going by when I either didn't get promoted to this or moved into that, and I had spent a couple years in the marketing side of the natural gas liquids business, and I think he sensed that I needed long-term growth and greater challenge ahead, and so when this idea of the venture capital subsidiary went around at the Mitchell management, I think on the basis of my broader
skill package in that I had technical, operational, financial, marketing skills that that might be the type of person.
And I really believe it was Bruce Withers who nominated me to either George Mitchell, Bud Clark, or Mike Richman for the position.
And we visited about it for a couple months.
And it really

attracted me from a personality profile, my tendency has always been if I want to buy a dog or if I want to buy a car, you know, every reference book that I can get, every piece of information, I just consume myself with it.
And I think in retrospect, that is a good personality profile for someone to be in venture capital because we're, you know, we're...

The fact that we chose to focus in the medical biomedical technology area doesn't mean that to understand the difference between a company and positron emissions tomography versus biotechnology is any less onerous than understanding a company in the oil business or a company in the steel business.
It's really something that you need to consume yourself with.
So it was attractive to me, and so they chose me to come in and run the venture subsidiary, and that was about in 1984, late 83, early 84.
And it was the first company that was on the wall in December.
Right, right, December of 84.
Yeah, so that really must have been...

late 83, early 84, because one of the more intelligent things that I think we did was, again, just as Mitchell apparently had handed to Richmond, said make it happen, Richmond handed to me, said no one really had any idea of what the venture capital subsidiary should do, whether we should invest in existing companies and new companies and computer companies and this company.
And what I did was I was most interested in making it successful.
I was not, I believed from day one that you could not operate a venture capital subsidiary for the purpose of, quote, economic development.
I believed that it had to be purely success driven with economic development coming as a result.
not as a purpose.
What's the background for that belief?
Well, the background for that belief, in my mind, was that the venture business was a tough business to start with.
And historically, if you invest in 10 companies, if you're lucky, one is a smashing success, a couple do OK, a couple do pretty bad, and two or three outright fail.

And if that was the history in a broader venture capital strategy, the idea that we could use a really what was a relatively small venture fund, a $15 million to attract not an average, but the best of companies to participate in the woodlands, my attitude was that
If a company, if it's an existing company and it's got good management and it's got a good story, good product to tell, it doesn't need to move anywhere to attract its capital.
Someone, wherever they may be, they'll be able to attract the capital to run their company.

I believe that if we took that strategy of only financing companies that would be willing to come participate in the woodlands, we'd be getting basically people that couldn't get their money elsewhere, and it would be a failing strategy.
In fact, in my opinion, that is what happened with that first company, which I'll come to.
But what I did was to manage a small venture fund.
I spent the better part of a year doing no investing but really studying how to make this successful.
And one of the things I determined was that back in that period of time, the early 80s, was a period of enormous growth in venture capital nationwide where the
Excuse me, I wanted to ask you, at some point, would you comment, in 1984 now, we're entering the demise of high fuel prices, and so with the collapse in Texas, how did that
Well, it really, at that time, again, I always look at the real demise occurred mostly in 86.
I think in the spring of 86 is when they went real down.
They went down some, but people still took the attitude in 84 that, well, it's temporary.
It'll come back up.
It's always going to come back up.
That's the attitude.
I looked at budgets in Mitchell for years and years, and always in the fifth year,
Prices were back up there, so there was generally that attitude and no concern that energy prices were going to go down long term.
What I was more concerned about was, you know, how are we going to make this thing work?
And what I saw was, although we are going into a period of time when, you know, venture capital, the fund sizes, the total amount of venture capital under management nationwide was growing,
You know, that's typically when you worry a little bit.
Well, everybody's jumping on the bandwagon.
You know, everybody's doing this.
You know, the proverbial California real estate fear that sooner or later the bubble's got to burst, although in that example, you know, it's only starting to show signs of that happening now.
But what I was afraid of was I saw a lot of venture firms that were small to medium size that were trying to emulate the strategy of the larger venture firms.
There were these large firms, the Hambrick and Quist and the Kleiner Perkins that could successfully invest in biotechnology in San Diego and in telecommunications in Boston because
they had the resources, the capital, and they had the expertise within their firms to be able to do that.
But what I saw was a whole bunch of small to medium sized venture funds trying to do the same thing.
And if you're a small venture fund with two or three partners, the likelihood that you have the intellectual capability to understand

telecommunications and biotechnology much less spend the amount your time there requires to travel to Boston travel San Diego you know it didn't make sense to me so I applying that for our you know fun to be successful not only did we have to have a regional orientation which is what I was handed to start with but we needed to be industry-oriented what I didn't think we could do in my opinion was
I didn't really want to have anything to do with the computer electronics industry.
We would have just been the 115th venture fund to invest in the 197th Winchester disk drive company.
We had no particular expertise.
We had nothing that would indicate to me that we were going to be any better than the next guy at doing that.
So what I did was I looked at what were the strengths of our region.
I considered space commercialization.
And despite how unpopular it was politically to say that isn't where we want to put our money at that time in Houston,
Privately, there's no way that a small venture fund can particularly participate in that type of industry.
Agriculture was attractive to me, and I felt Texas had the infrastructure to do that.
But that wasn't my number one choice, and I've always said that's something I'm going to do down the road maybe.
The microelectronics, telecommunications, we do have some infrastructure here in Texas for that in the San Antonio-Austin-Dallas corridor.
But again, I've tended to be a contrarian by nature, and where everybody else is placing their bet, that's fine, and I'm not going to necessarily bet against it, but I'm not going to.
Typically what happens is,
It gets overpriced, overbid, and it doesn't become attractive.
So I wasn't interested in that.
In the years that I spent with Pete Marwick, I had some health care clients.
That industry always fascinated me.
We were starting to hear more about biotechnology.

uh... you know with uh... some background in chemistry uh... you know it's funny because within our firm now uh... i have the chemical background and i tend to believe the world is chemistry d n a r four base pairs of proteins are twenty amino acids one of my partner's background is in biology and he looks at the world is being biologically driven but nonetheless uh...
We thought that that was something that just we had an incredible untapped resource here, not just in Houston, but in Texas.
And what we did was we determined that the academic institutions here in Houston were spending about a quarter of a billion dollars a year on research and development and

you add in another half dozen outside of houston within texas and europe to a half billion dollars a year of research and development in the life sciences area and this equated would equate to an enormous pharmaceutical or or health care company this is a lot of money but was was maybe even more significant to me was the fact that this wasn't
research done out in the plains of Kansas, which was for the sake of science, the reproductive cycle of the Drosilla fly.
That may be scientifically interesting, but might not have any clinical significance.
What we had here in Houston particularly was these symbiotic relationships, Baylor College of Medicine, Methodist Hospital, UT Cancer Center, MD Anderson, et cetera, et cetera.
And what that meant to me was that people that were writing the research grants were having lunch with the doctors that were trying to save lives.
And overall, I felt that much more of the research being done here would be clinically driven.
instead of driven for the pure advancement of science.
And that was just an inherent field.

What I did, though, is I looked nationally and found, and this surprises me, and it has changed much since then, but back in 1983, if you took the pie where venture capital nationwide had been invested, you found that there was a slice there for health care.
But if you subdivided the health care slice

to extricate from it that amount of venture capital they've gone to what I'll call the delivery system, hospital management, HMOs, things like that, meaning the residual slice of that pie would be medical, biomedical technology versus services.
The percentage was incredibly small.
It was less than 5%.
And when you're talking, you know,

whatever, $200 billion U.S. healthcare industry, that seemed to be a very small slice of a pie, that it was an industry that, in my opinion, then and still today is one of the maybe even few, I hate to use that word, but one of the few industries where the United States still has a strong technological leadership.
So that was attractive to me.
The money, venture capital money, is going to services, HMO-type operations?
There was, but even that, even if you didn't extricate the services slice of the pie, the slice of that pie for health care was not very big.
And there were only a couple venture capital firms back in 83 that could say,
you know, that they invest even as little as a third of their capital in the healthcare area.
Why do you think that was?
Was it because of government regulations?
Well, I think regulatory issues probably discouraged a lot of people.
You've got to understand, the venture industry was built upon and grown from computers.
I mean, the Silicon Valley phenomenon.
Consequently,
Most venture capitalists that have technical backgrounds, it's electrical engineering.
People that knew bits and bytes didn't know monoclonal antibodies and recombinant DNA.
One of the things that Dr. Lamb mentioned is that
FDA and various regulatory agencies demand rigorous testing and what have you before.
Something which may have been developed actually becomes a marketable product.
There's a long...
There is.
And to me, that does not act as strong an impediment to me as to invest in health care.
Because on the same token, that acts as a barrier to entry for your competitors.
So there's a flip side to that coin.

What it really does, though, is it makes in a world market, which we're more and more into every day, it makes U.S. companies less competitive on a worldwide basis because it takes them more of their capital and more of their time to get products approved in their home market.
Right.
But from a venture capital perspective, it wasn't as big a consideration maybe as Dominic felt it would be.
But in any event, I sold everybody on that strategy that we would focus on that.
But keep in mind that the Mitchell organization was still pretty much of the mindset that this was a woodlands-oriented thing.
Interesting.
The first company we end up investing in was Key Concepts, which was an electronics company, had electronic keyboards for computers.
Now, that deal came to us, was referred to us by Lloyd Benson III, and I turned it down.
And it came in again, and I turned it down a second time.
But the next thing I knew was...
The people up here were hearing things like, well, these people can lease 20,000 square feet of space.
And all of a sudden, the powers that be, and I won't use names, but eventually was determined that we should put a little bit of money in and take a little risk on this one.
And in fact, in retrospect, it was probably the best thing that ever happened to me.
Because this was a company that failed.

And in fact, if that company had succeeded, then what we would have been doing, then I would have been fighting this battle of that you just invest in companies that are willing to move to the woodlands.
But in fact, not only did it fail, but I think
It actually was kind of an embarrassment that a company that leased all that space and employed quite a few people became a failure.
That didn't happen overnight, and there was no direct link to it.
But in all candor, I've always believed that that was probably one of the more important elements to the ultimate success of our venture capital program.
Thereafter, people, I think, were more convinced that, no, you can't just do this as a real estate tool.
This, in fact, is a business in its own self.
I have always held that the economic development of the woodlands will be the result of the success of the venture program, but

I have always, and the reason that I always felt that tying the venture capital activities to the woodlands, even in that way, was acceptable was the fact that what we also chose as a role to play in our venture program was that we would work with the universities around the state to set up new companies as a result of their technology.
Well, when you're setting up a new company,
you know, whether they're located here, down the street, you know, in the next county, you know, it's inconsequential generally to the people involved.
But what we also felt was, you know, those companies, we knew many of those companies would be the biotechnology type companies.
And again, I have always been cognizant of the fact that these companies that we are, we're in a world business.
Everything is a world business today.
And I always place Texas as being a country and every other state is another country.
And, you know, the economic welfare of Texas is not only
you know, what products that we can ship to Japan but what products we can ship to Idaho or what products from Idaho that come into Texas that we can learn to make here.
And one of the things I recognized was that, you know, the business of biotechnology was an intellectual business.
And it meant that the people that were, you know, that made up the workforce of these companies were,

uh... highly trained highly skilled highly educated uh... fairly well paid for the most part and we were entering a period where they were in great demand where you know a protein chemist might have languished in an academic laboratory for twenty years and all of a sudden a protein chemist you know he's like uh... a designated hitter in the american league you know he writes his own ticket if we're gonna if we're gonna create successful companies uh... we're gonna be competing
We're not going to be competing against companies in Dallas and companies in Fort Worth.
We're going to be competing against companies in San Francisco and San Diego and in Boston.
And if we're going to hire the best intellectual talent to be able to compete with those companies, we have to offer the package.
Why would someone come to work in Houston?

to work for a biotechnology company if they can, as an alternative, they can go to work in Palo Alto, particularly where, you know, scientific people might be a little bit more risk averse, whereas if that company happened to fail, there's another company right down the street that they can go to work to.
They've got, you know, they've got a culture there.
They've got, you know, the physical beauty of California or wherever.
And what we opined was to be able to recruit management, which we didn't have.
We've got all this technology here, but never having a prevalent or a dominating health care industry or medical technology industry here, we don't have a good pool of management people.
So, A, we knew we were going to be recruiting senior management people, and we'd be recruiting them from California and Boston and New Jersey.
B, we knew that we would have to be recruiting scientists, and we'd be having to recruit those scientists from the same places.
I find that even though maybe the Mitchell organization saw the woodlands as the primary mission initially, what I saw was that my primary mission was to finance successful companies.
If they all moved to the woodlands but all failed, then we'd have wasted not only our investment dollars, but all the dollars that went into providing them space and all that.
But I felt that to enhance my ability to grow successful companies, that the Woodlands was a genuine tool.
I felt that when I, and in all candor, I've spent as much time recruiting people as I have doing anything else.
And I cannot attract people from California to come to live in the city of Houston to a large degree.
And one of the biggest problems, they land at the airport and they see sign pollution all the way into town.
And you've already lost them.
You haven't even had dinner yet and you've lost them.
So we actually here in our organization, we saw our ability to take what was world-class technology, which we had capital, which is the most generic of all this.
But the third part of the triangle was management and people.
We saw our only way, perhaps, or our equalizing way to recruit the best people was to offer this, what I believe is this incredible, you know, element, environment of the woodlands.
So I use that more as a tool to grow successful companies.
The result, excuse me, has been that our program has been highly successful and as a result has,

has produced this economic development of the woodlands, and now, fortunately, has produced a real critical mass where there's probably nowhere else in Texas, even though it's small by California standards, there's no place in Texas where there's more of a critical mass of privatized life science companies than we have here in the woodlands.
Could you recalibrate?
the development of some of that critical mass?
Sure, sure.
It was, and again, we take, you know, right now we look back and to summarize, we have 17 or 18 companies that we have financed through the Mitchell subsidiary and now our private organization.
We became independent of Mitchell in 88, 89.
Rough, basically a third of those companies are here in the woodlands and

A part of our skills, of those 18 companies, I would say eight or nine of those companies existed from the transfer of technology from an academic institution, generally where we played the role of the founders of the company.
As an example, the very first company that we acted as a lead investor in, the very first company that was

created as a result in texas as a result of technology transfer of academic laboratory was a company out of baylor college of medicine in 1985 called cardiovascular systems and cardiovascular systems which later became known by the name amnion inc was formed to commercialize a what we call an autologous blood transfusion system it was developed at baylor college of medicine
somewhat under the direction of people in Michael DeBakey's group.

And what they sought was an ability during a surgical procedure, particularly a thoracic-type procedure where there was blood loss, whether in the old days, bypass surgery produced a lot more blood loss than it does today, but these aortic aneurysm procedures and all that, there's a high amount of blood loss.
Two things were problematic even before the AIDS epidemic.
One was that the availability of blood, the ability to transfuse enough blood to keep these patients alive.
And number two, with donor transfused blood or homologous transfusion, which means the blood from someone else, there was clinically a fairly significant risk associated with non-A, non-B hepatitis.
And even today, non-A, non-B, hepatitis is clinically much higher a risk factor than AIDS is.
But nonetheless, the doctors were familiar with this risk way back.
And so what Dr. DeBakey wanted was a better way to, and they had some more modest systems that would take a patient's blood during surgical procedure, recycle it,
But it would do maybe one unit of blood every 20 minutes.
Well, in one of these aneurysm patients, you might need to go through six or seven units of blood in 20 minutes.

So making a long story short, they developed a system that would take the blood, it would run it through a filter, then it would run it through a centrifuge separating the red cells from the plasma and platelets, wash down those red cells
and re-infuse those red cells, a unit of red cells to the patient.
And it was capable of doing this in a matter of two or three minutes.
So it meant that you could almost keep real time up.
And that not only produced much less risk of a transfusion-related disease, but just in terms of blood, we had a patient in California after we started selling these from a small hospital

that they went through, you know, your body holds roughly 17 to 20 units of blood, but if it's going in and out, this particular case, they used, they salvaged what they estimate was something like 150, 170 units of blood.
Yeah, it was, you know, just blood in, blood out for, you know, the eight hours they were doing this procedure.
And in this particular case, the patient died.
But what was those people at that little hospital in California were just so happy about was, you know, that could have been the worst case.
Not only did they lose a patient, but they would have wiped out the entire blood bank.
And for everybody else that needed blood, they would not have had any.
So this product was an attractive product.
It was patented.
There was a patent ultimately received on a bowl.
But what was interesting was, and to this date,

That product, that technology, if you will, I'd rather call it a product than a technology, but that particular product had the lowest technological profile and addressed the smallest market, as sexy as it may seem, of all the companies that we've since helped create.
But nonetheless, we took advantage of that.
We took advantage particularly of the fact that we had a startup company, but yet

When we launched that product, we had a startup company, but we had a product that had been clinically utilized at Baylor, at Henry Ford Hospital, at the Mayo Clinic, at a variety of attractive clinical sites.
How did the connection come between you and the company initially?
What they had was they initially at Baylor, they tried to raise a partnership that was going to fund a bushel basket of projects.
And that

was never successful they were never able to raise that money and one of those projects that was in that partnership was it was labeled a continuous blood auto transfusion system and i said well if they're if you know you're going to develop a continuous blood auto transfusion system does that mean that there exists today a discontinuous blood auto transfusion system and they said yes and i asked them how
rapidly it would cycle a unit of blood.
And I said, you know, gee, that's pretty good just what you have right there.
Why don't we evaluate whether that product is commercially viable?
And we did so.
And so we set up the company called Cardiovascular Systems.
We became the lead investor in the company.
I hired Don Spirison, who is now my partner,
to run that.
He became the president of that company back in 85.
And in a nutshell, we financed that company in June of 85 with $1.5 million.
By March-April of 86, it had shipped its first product.
By the second quarter of 87, it hit its first profitable month.
And by 1988,
it had sustained profitability on a monthly basis.
And we ended up selling it for approximately $15 million to COBE Laboratories in 1988.
So that was, if we could create that success with such a low technology and a small market product, it very much encouraged us that some of the other things that we had done subsequent to that
would have even higher potential.
When you set up the venture, your investment in this company, you buy stock, is that how you fund it?
Right, right.
So when you sold for $15 million, you sold your stock or the total?
The total, the total package.
Of which part was yours?
Of which part was ours.
What we have done, and again, these technology transfer ventures have been the ones that we have made our prized,
place that we have here in our own backyard.
The other thing was venture capitalists had not had a historically real good relationship with academia, the alleged vulture capitalism.
And one of the other things that I did early on was I decided that if we're going to do this, we had to be able to wear white hats.
If we couldn't be good guys and be successful at this, well, then we need to get in another business at Pitt.

And what we chose as, we studied working with academia, and what we found in California, for example, venture capitalists would typically create a company, and then they would bring in the scientists as employees, full-time employees of that company, and, you know, license and technology and all that.
But what that was doing was, you know, it was robbing the institutions of some of their best people.
and hence the vulture capitalist thing.
And I thought, jeez, there's got to be a better formula.
Plus, I didn't like the idea of just licensing.
I thought we needed to find a mechanism where everybody was on the same playing field, where it was a we type of a thing instead of a we versus they.

And our prescription for that was to make sure that everybody had the same vested ownership and that what we would do when we created a new company, we would set up a new company, in this case, Cardiovascular Systems.

We would provide for licensing the technology from Baylor College of Medicine to the company that Baylor would get equity, would get stock ownership, that the investigator who had developed the technology

would get equity ownership in the company, that we, through our capital investment, would get equity ownership, and then management that we brought in through their earning their equity by running the company, they would have equity ownership.
And consequently, we are all interested and we would all benefit in the success or be hurt by the failure in the same way.
So there wasn't any games to be played.
Is there any formula for control of the company management?
Did you carefully avoid having 51% of the stock?
Well, we're not opposed to having control.
On the other hand, it is varied on a deal by deal.
Some venture capitalists are overwhelmingly concerned about control.
In our case,
We weren't.
We took the attitude that, you know, we're going to be pretty darn selective of the people we're going to do business with.
Well, in all honesty, it's in all candor that it has, you know, generally as a rule of thumb, it has been more of a problem as a venture capitalist when you don't have control.
And the reason you're concerned about control is not when times are going good, but when times are going bad.
And one thing that we did want to avoid was, again, we allowed this ownership to happen despite the fact that we left the academic scientist at the academic institution.
And we paid, you know, we might have paid them a little as a consultant, but we didn't rob those people.
Number one, we wanted the Baylor administration to think kindly enough of us so that we could do deal number two and deal number 13
But also, we didn't want to have academic scientists believing that they could run companies either and involved in the day-to-day management of the company.
We gave everybody the same vested interest, but we wanted everybody to have their appropriate role within the venture.
Interestingly, at that time, we could do that with Baylor.
But back when we started doing that in 85, we could not do that with any of the state institutions.

And in fact, I personally spent a lot of trips to Austin to help participate in the drafting of House Bill 1402, which was passed, I think, in 86, which then allowed the state institutions and their faculty members to have stock in companies that were commercially launched.
When was that passed?
That was passed in 1986.
And we, after Cardiovascular Systems, we were actually the founder of the first company commercial enterprise launched from any of the University of Texas, 13 components.
That company was called Life Cell Corporation, and that came out of the Health Science Center here in Houston.
That company's here in the Woodlands.
And we were also involved in the creation of the first company out of the University of Texas, MD Anderson.
about that same period, a company now called Argus Pharmaceuticals, which is here in the Woodlands.
Let me follow up on something that we started and straightened up.
You were giving us this case study about cardiovascular systems.
One of the things you mentioned earlier was it was sold.
Henry asked you about control and what have you.
How was the decision made?
How did the... To sell?
How was the decision made?
The Board of Directors makes that decision.
In this particular case, the venture capitalists did own more than 50, collectively, all the venture capitalists that were in that deal owned more than 50% of the stock.
But the venture, we had debate over what we should do.
In that particular case, an interesting case study, our reason to sell, and we're at a time when the company was profitable, was growing,
It was beating its major competitor, a company 10 times its size, three out of four times that we would take them on head-to-head in the marketplace.
We were beating them.
The problem was multifold.
One is that, fine, we are beating them three out of four times we are taking them on head-to-head.
They were growing like crazy, too, because they were finding three or four other hospitals that we could never reach because we had a limited sales force of about six people.
And we could not justify growing our sales force on that single product alone because, again, the market was relatively small.
What we needed was we needed another product or two to add to our sales people's efforts so we could justify a large sales force.
We spent the better part of a year trying to identify a product or a company to acquire, and we actually came up with one.
We negotiated a letter of intent to acquire the Sorensen product line from Abbott Laboratories.
The problem was that we had a difficult time financing that acquisition, because this was now, when we did this, this was in 88, and Texas banks were in bad shape then.
And what happened was that this was an acquisition that I believe the total acquisition price was about $9 million.
We didn't want to, we wanted to put in, say, maybe a seven, somewhere seven.
We wanted to put about half of it in as equity and half of it in as debt.
We didn't want to over leverage the company.
And the company was now profitable.
The acquisition could clearly show that its cash flow could
service the debt.
The problem was that Texas banks weren't doing anything.
The deal was attractive to out-of-state banks, but because we were only looking to borrow $3 or $4 million, the out-of-state banks said, well, we just can't loan that small amount.
We'd have to do 5 to 10 to be able to get it approved.
